\section{Monte Carlo Experiment}

\subsection{Data generating process}

Consider the following structural model:

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & a_{12}^{j} & a_{13}^{j}\\
0 & 1 & 0\\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t+1}\\
f_{t+1}\\
m_{t+1}
\end{array}\right]= & \left[\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\\
0\\
0
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
b_{11}^{j} & b_{12}^{j} & b_{13}^{j}\\
0 & b_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & b_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t}\\
f_{t}\\
m_{t}
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
c_{11}^{j} & 0 & 0\\
0 & c_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & c_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
\epsilon_{1,t}\\
\epsilon_{2,t}\\
\epsilon_{3,t}
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

Or in compact notation:

\begin{align*}
A_{j}X_{t+1}= & C+B_{j}X_{t}+\Omega_{j}^{1/2}\epsilon_{t}
\end{align*}

Where we have that $j=\{0,1\}$ corresponding to the bad and normal
regime respectively. Then it is easy to show that:

\begin{align*}
A_{j}^{-1}= & \left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -a_{12}^{j} & -a_{13}^{j}\\
0 & 1 & 0\\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

We can the write the reduced form of the system:

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t+1}\\
f_{t+1}\\
m_{t+1}
\end{array}\right]= & \left[\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\\
0\\
0
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -a_{12}^{j} & -a_{13}^{j}\\
0 & 1 & 0\\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
b_{11}^{j} & b_{12}^{j} & b_{13}^{j}\\
0 & b_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & b_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t}\\
f_{t}\\
m_{t}
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & -a_{12}^{j} & -a_{13}^{j}\\
0 & 1 & 0\\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
c_{11}^{j} & 0 & 0\\
0 & c_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & c_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
\epsilon_{1,t}\\
\epsilon_{2,t}\\
\epsilon_{3,t}
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

Simple operations yield

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t+1}\\
f_{t+1}\\
m_{t+1}
\end{array}\right]= & \left[\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\\
0\\
0
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
b_{11}^{j} & b_{12}^{j}-a_{12}^{j}b_{22} & b_{13}^{j}-a_{13}^{j}b_{33}\\
0 & b_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & b_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t}\\
f_{t}\\
m_{t}
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
c_{11}^{j} & -a_{12}^{j}c_{22} & -a_{13}^{j}c_{33}\\
0 & c_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & c_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
\epsilon_{1,t}\\
\epsilon_{2,t}\\
\epsilon_{3,t}
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

This representation clearly shows that the shocks to the first equation
are composites of the structural shocks to the $f_{t}$ and $m_{t}$
factors. Moreover, by construction we can impose $c_{22}=c_{33}=1$,
which implies that the financial and macro factors have unit variance.
Then we can write the reduced form system:

\begin{eqnarray}
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t+1}\\
f_{t+1}\\
m_{t+1}
\end{array}\right]= & \left[\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\\
0\\
0
\end{array}\right] & +\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
b_{11}^{j} & b_{12}^{j}-a_{12}^{j}b_{22} & b_{13}^{j}-a_{13}^{j}b_{33}\\
0 & b_{22} & 0\\
0 & 0 & b_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t}\\
f_{t}\\
m_{t}
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{c}
\eta_{1,t}\\
\eta_{2,t}\\
\eta_{3,t}
\end{array}\right]
\end{eqnarray}

Where $\eta_{t}\sim N(0,A_{j}^{-1}\Omega_{j}A_{j}^{-1'})$ and where
it is clear the following mapping bettwen reduced form $(\eta)$ and
structural shocks $(\epsilon)$:

\begin{align*}
\eta_{1,t}= & c_{11}^{j}\epsilon_{1,t}-a_{12}^{j}\epsilon_{2,t}-a_{13}^{j}\epsilon_{3,t}\\
\eta_{2.t}= & \epsilon_{2,t}\\
\eta_{3.t}= & \epsilon_{3,t}
\end{align*}


\subsection{Coefficient restrictions}

Focusing on the first equation of the system we have

\begin{eqnarray*}
\begin{array}{c}
y_{t+1}\end{array} & =\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\end{array}+b_{11}^{j}y_{t}+\left(b_{12}^{j}-a_{12}^{j}b_{22}\right)f_{t}+\left(b_{13}^{j}-a_{13}^{j}b_{33}\right)m_{t}+\eta_{1,t}
\end{eqnarray*}

If we impose $b_{11}^{j}=0$, we arrive at the one-step-ahead forecasting
equation we have in the paper:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\begin{array}{c}
y_{t+1}\end{array} & =\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\end{array}+\beta_{j}f_{t}+\gamma_{j}m_{t}+\eta_{1,t}
\end{eqnarray*}

We restrict attention to the following parameter restrictions to match
our empirical framework:

\begin{eqnarray*}
\beta_{j} & <0\\
\gamma_{j} & >0\\
\beta_{0} & < & \beta_{1}\\
\gamma_{0} & > & \gamma_{1}
\end{eqnarray*}

\section{Alternative DGP}

The issue with the previous DGP is that $m_t$ and $f_t$ are independent from $y_{t}$, hence inference about the regimes is difficult once we try to estimate the model. 

\begin{eqnarray}
\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t}\\
f_{t+1}\\
m_{t+1}
\end{array}\right]= & \left[\begin{array}{c}
\mu^{j}\\
0\\
0
\end{array}\right] & +\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & \beta^j & \gamma^j\\
0 & b_{22} & b_{23}\\
0 & b_{32} & b_{33}
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
y_{t-1}\\
f_{t}\\
m_{t}
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{c}
\eta_{1,t}\\
\eta_{2,t}\\
\eta_{3,t}
\end{array}\right]
\end{eqnarray}
